contentrichtext.text: '''Qasim Barid I''' (r.1489-1504) was a prime-minister of the [[Bahmani sultanate]] and the founder of the [[Bidar Sultanate]], one of the five late medieval [[India]]n kingdoms together known as the [[Deccan sultanates]]. Qasim Barid was a Turk, domiciled in Georgia or muslim (Shia) Georgian.<ref>{{cite book |last=Beale |first=Thomas William |title=ORIENTAL BIOGRAPHICAL DICTIONARY |year=1894 |page=317}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Constable |first=Archibald |title=Travels in the Mogul Empire, AD 1656-1668 (Francois Bernier) |year=1994 |page=192}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Gribble |first=JD |title=History of the Decan |year=1990 |page=168}}</ref> He entered the service of the Bahmani sultan Muhammad Shah III. He later became the prime-minister of the Bahmani sultanate.<ref name=majumdar>Majumdar, R.C. (ed.) (2007). ''The Mughul Empire'', Mumbai:Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, {{Listed Invalid ISBN|81-7276-407-1}}, p.466</ref> Some have claimed that Qasim Barid was of Hungarian descent.<ref>[http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/citation/s5-VII/178/408-b QASIM, THE HUNGARIAN FOUNDER OF THE BARID SHAHI DYNASTY OF AHMADABAD BIDR, IN SOUTHERN INDIA - ELLIS s5-VII (178): 408 - Notes and Queries<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Qasim Barid I led one of the first revolts against the [[Bahmani]] Sultanate. He was able to get himself made chief of state but had seriously undermined the stability of the kingdom.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/topic-485561/Qasim-Barid Qasim Barid (Bahmani minister) - Britannica Online Encyclopedia<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Bahmani governors of Junnar, Bijapur and Berar refused to acknowledge the authority of Qasim Barid and in June,1490 Malik Ahmad Nizam-ul-Mulk, the governor of Junnar founded the independent [[Ahmednagar Sultanate]] followed by the foundation of the independent [[Bijapur Sultanate]] by Yusuf Adil Khan and [[Berar Sultanate]] by Fathullh Imad-ul-Mulk in the same year.<ref>Majumdar, R.C. (ed.) (2006). ''The Delhi Sultanate'', Mumbai:Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, p.268</ref> The founding of the dynasty occurred in 1492.<ref>[http://www.webindia123.com/history/MEDIEVAL/delhisultanate/delhisultantate5.htm webindia123.com-Indian History-Medieval-Delhisultanate-THE BAHMANI DYNASTY OF THE DECCAN<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Qasim Barid died in 1504 and was succeeded by his son Amir Barid I, as the prime minister of the [[Bahmani Sultanate]] who also became the de facto ruler like his father.<ref name="majumdar"/> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Barid, Qasim 01 | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1504 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barid, Qasim 01}} [[Category:1504 deaths]] [[Category:Shia Muslim dynasties]] [[Category:Deccan sultanates]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]
